pullrequest.title: [Gazebo9] Enabling dynamic linking for Windows build

content.raw:
this causes a linking error our Ubuntu builds with gcc:

* [![Build Status](https://build.osrfoundation.org/buildStatus/icon?job=gazebo-ci-pr_any-xenial-amd64-gpu-none&build=1019)](https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any-xenial-amd64-gpu-none/1019/) https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any-xenial-amd64-gpu-none/1019/
* [![Build Status](https://build.osrfoundation.org/buildStatus/icon?job=gazebo-ci-pr_any-xenial-amd64-gpu-nvidia&build=774)](https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any-xenial-amd64-gpu-nvidia/774/) https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any-xenial-amd64-gpu-nvidia/774/

~~~
libgazebo_gui.so.9.6.0: undefined reference to `gazebo::common::EnumIface<gazebo::common::MaterialType>::names'
collect2: error: ld returned 1 exit status
~~~
content.html:
this causes a linking error our Ubuntu builds with gcc:

  • https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any-xenial-amd64-gpu-none/1019/
  • https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any-xenial-amd64-gpu-nvidia/774/
libgazebo_gui.so.9.6.0: undefined reference to `gazebo::common::EnumIface<gazebo::common::MaterialType>::names'
collect2: error: ld returned 1 exit status

content.raw:
I started a new round of builds, and it looks like the Ubuntu jobs have completed the build and are running tests:

* [![Build Status](https://build.osrfoundation.org/buildStatus/icon?job=gazebo-ci-pr_any-xenial-amd64-gpu-nvidia&build=776)](https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any-xenial-amd64-gpu-nvidia/776/) https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any-xenial-amd64-gpu-nvidia/776/
* [![Build Status](https://build.osrfoundation.org/buildStatus/icon?job=gazebo-ci-pr_any-xenial-amd64-gpu-none&build=1021)](https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any-xenial-amd64-gpu-none/1021/) https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any-xenial-amd64-gpu-none/1021/

the windows build is still fine, though with some additional compiler warnings

* [![Build Status](https://build.osrfoundation.org/buildStatus/icon?job=gazebo-ci-pr_any-windows7-amd64&build=2447)](https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any-windows7-amd64/2447/) https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any-windows7-amd64/2447/

unfortunately, the homebrew build is now failing

* [![Build Status](https://build.osrfoundation.org/buildStatus/icon?job=gazebo-ci-pr_any-homebrew-amd64&build=1654)](https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any-homebrew-amd64/1654/) https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any-homebrew-amd64/1654/

~~~
gazebo/common/MaterialDensity.cc:25:1: error: explicit specialization of 'range' after instantiation
GZ_ENUM(GZ_COMMON_VISIBLE,
^
gazebo/common/EnumIface.hh:43:34: note: expanded from macro 'GZ_ENUM'
    common::EnumIface<enumType>::range[] = {begin, end}; \
                                 ^
gazebo/common/EnumIface.hh:60:16: note: implicit instantiation first required here
        return range[0];
               ^
gazebo/common/MaterialDensity.cc:25:1: error: explicit specialization of 'names' after instantiation
GZ_ENUM(GZ_COMMON_VISIBLE,
^
gazebo/common/EnumIface.hh:45:59: note: expanded from macro 'GZ_ENUM'
    std::vector<std::string> common::EnumIface<enumType>::names = {__VA_ARGS__};
                                                          ^
gazebo/common/EnumIface.hh:77:45: note: implicit instantiation first required here
        if (static_cast<unsigned int>(_e) < names.size())
                                            ^
2 errors generated.
~~~
content.html:
I started a new round of builds, and it looks like the Ubuntu jobs have completed the build and are running tests:

  • https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any-xenial-amd64-gpu-nvidia/776/
  • https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any-xenial-amd64-gpu-none/1021/

the windows build is still fine, though with some additional compiler warnings

  • https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any-windows7-amd64/2447/

unfortunately, the homebrew build is now failing

  • https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any-homebrew-amd64/1654/
gazebo/common/MaterialDensity.cc:25:1: error: explicit specialization of 'range' after instantiation
GZ_ENUM(GZ_COMMON_VISIBLE,
^
gazebo/common/EnumIface.hh:43:34: note: expanded from macro 'GZ_ENUM'
    common::EnumIface<enumType>::range[] = {begin, end}; \
                                 ^
gazebo/common/EnumIface.hh:60:16: note: implicit instantiation first required here
        return range[0];
               ^
gazebo/common/MaterialDensity.cc:25:1: error: explicit specialization of 'names' after instantiation
GZ_ENUM(GZ_COMMON_VISIBLE,
^
gazebo/common/EnumIface.hh:45:59: note: expanded from macro 'GZ_ENUM'
    std::vector<std::string> common::EnumIface<enumType>::names = {__VA_ARGS__};
                                                          ^
gazebo/common/EnumIface.hh:77:45: note: implicit instantiation first required here
        if (static_cast<unsigned int>(_e) < names.size())
                                            ^
2 errors generated.

pullrequest.title: [Gazebo9] Enabling dynamic linking for Windows build

content.raw: Thank Steven! I reordered the explicit specialization & instantiation to conform with C\+\+ standards on this.
content.html: Thank Steven! I reordered the explicit specialization & instantiation to conform with C++ standards on this.

pullrequest.title: [Gazebo9] Enabling dynamic linking for Windows build

content.raw:
I just tried compiling on my desktop Ubuntu machine, and the build proceeds farther, but still fails to link `gzclient`:

~~~
[ 75%] Linking CXX executable gzclient
libgazebo_gui.so.9.6.0: undefined reference to `gazebo::common::EnumIface<gazebo::common::MaterialType>::names'
libgazebo_gui.so.9.6.0: undefined reference to `gazebo::common::EnumIface<gazebo::common::MaterialType>::range'
collect2: error: ld returned 1 exit status
~~~
content.html:
I just tried compiling on my desktop Ubuntu machine, and the build proceeds farther, but still fails to link gzclient:

[ 75%] Linking CXX executable gzclient
libgazebo_gui.so.9.6.0: undefined reference to `gazebo::common::EnumIface<gazebo::common::MaterialType>::names'
libgazebo_gui.so.9.6.0: undefined reference to `gazebo::common::EnumIface<gazebo::common::MaterialType>::range'
collect2: error: ld returned 1 exit status

pullrequest.title: [Gazebo9] Enabling dynamic linking for Windows build

content.raw: It turned out the visible attributes for the template class EnumIface between gcc and msvc are different and I decided to conditionally define GZ\_ENUM to handle this case. I reworked the change and compiled successfully both on my Ubuntu Desktop and Windows machine. Please take a look thanks!
content.html: It turned out the visible attributes for the template class EnumIface between gcc and msvc are different and I decided to conditionally define GZ_ENUM to handle this case. I reworked the change and compiled successfully both on my Ubuntu Desktop and Windows machine. Please take a look thanks!

pullrequest.title: [Gazebo9] Enabling dynamic linking for Windows build

content.raw:
I started a new round of builds after 7215f80:

* [![Build Status](https://build.osrfoundation.org/buildStatus/icon?job=gazebo-ci-pr_any-windows7-amd64&build=2448)](https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any-windows7-amd64/2448/) https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any-windows7-amd64/2448/
* [![Build Status](https://build.osrfoundation.org/buildStatus/icon?job=gazebo-ci-pr_any-homebrew-amd64&build=1656)](https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any-homebrew-amd64/1656/) https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any-homebrew-amd64/1656/
* [![Build Status](https://build.osrfoundation.org/buildStatus/icon?job=gazebo-ci-pr_any-xenial-amd64-gpu-nvidia&build=777)](https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any-xenial-amd64-gpu-nvidia/777/) https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any-xenial-amd64-gpu-nvidia/777/
* [![Build Status](https://build.osrfoundation.org/buildStatus/icon?job=gazebo-ci-pr_any-xenial-amd64-gpu-none&build=1023)](https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any-xenial-amd64-gpu-none/1023/) https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any-xenial-amd64-gpu-none/1023/

None of the builds are failing to compile now, but all the integration tests are failing on Ubuntu (though macOS is fine):

* https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any-xenial-amd64-gpu-nvidia/777/testReport/

I saw the following console output from some failing tests:

~~~
[Wrn] [SystemPaths.cc:445] File or path does not exist [""] [worlds/empty.world]
[Err] [Server.cc:382] Could not open file[worlds/empty.world]
~~~

This seems like the [SystemPaths class](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/bd1cdea8fa3d71d6afcdaa83c9b01891d5f72e71/gazebo/common/SystemPaths.hh?fileviewer=file-view-default#SystemPaths.hh-56) is not working properly. Since that class is a Singleton, it made me suspicious of the change to the `SingletonT.hh` file in this pull request. I tried reverting that change, and it fixed the problems with the tests.
content.html:
I started a new round of builds after 7215f80:

  • https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any-windows7-amd64/2448/
  • https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any-homebrew-amd64/1656/
  • https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any-xenial-amd64-gpu-nvidia/777/
  • https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any-xenial-amd64-gpu-none/1023/

None of the builds are failing to compile now, but all the integration tests are failing on Ubuntu (though macOS is fine):

  • https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any-xenial-amd64-gpu-nvidia/777/testReport/

I saw the following console output from some failing tests:

[Wrn] [SystemPaths.cc:445] File or path does not exist [""] [worlds/empty.world]
[Err] [Server.cc:382] Could not open file[worlds/empty.world]

This seems like the SystemPaths class is not working properly. Since that class is a Singleton, it made me suspicious of the change to the SingletonT.hh file in this pull request. I tried reverting that change, and it fixed the problems with the tests.

pullrequest.title: [Gazebo9] Enabling dynamic linking for Windows build

content.raw:
Good catch! I added the missing declaration for SensorManager. Also, I decided to conditionally define the GZ\_SINGLETON\_DECLARE for clang case \(hope that fixes the macOS build break\). And I noticed many failing test failures output `terminate called after throwing an instance of 'std::out_of_range'` message. I suspect that’s related to a [SystemPaths.cc](http://SystemPath.cc) issue, so I added a fix too.  
  
Can you please re-spin a new CI run? Thanks!
content.html:
Good catch! I added the missing declaration for SensorManager. Also, I decided to conditionally define the GZ_SINGLETON_DECLARE for clang case (hope that fixes the macOS build break). And I noticed many failing test failures output terminate called after throwing an instance of 'std::out_of_range' message. I suspect that’s related to a SystemPaths.cc issue, so I added a fix too.

Can you please re-spin a new CI run? Thanks!

content.raw:
yes, the tests are mostly passing, though there are some `gz` tests failing. I noticed that the `gz` command seg-faults on Ubuntu with a reference to `IntrospectionManager` teardown in the [backtrace](https://gist.github.com/scpeters/73c40f897755675e700f42c0fc35a561)

Here's the cppcheck complaints:

~~~
gazebo/common/EnumIface.hh:51:  Lines should be <= 80 characters long  [whitespace/line_length] [2]
Total errors found: 1
gazebo/common/SingletonT.hh:62:  Lines should be <= 80 characters long  [whitespace/line_length] [2]
Total errors found: 1
gazebo/sensors/SensorFactory.hh:64:  Lines should be <= 80 characters long  [whitespace/line_length] [2]
gazebo/sensors/SensorFactory.hh:71:  Lines should be <= 80 characters long  [whitespace/line_length] [2]
gazebo/sensors/SensorFactory.hh:76:  Lines should be <= 80 characters long  [whitespace/line_length] [2]
Total errors found: 3
~~~
content.html:
yes, the tests are mostly passing, though there are some gz tests failing. I noticed that the gz command seg-faults on Ubuntu with a reference to IntrospectionManager teardown in the backtrace

Here's the cppcheck complaints:

gazebo/common/EnumIface.hh:51:  Lines should be <= 80 characters long  [whitespace/line_length] [2]
Total errors found: 1

pullrequest.title: [Gazebo9] Enabling dynamic linking for Windows build

content.raw:
In my setup, I can see the gz SIGABRT in my case. The call stack looks similar. [https://gist.github.com/seanyen-msft/526825ad16de69550b075d511947cebc](https://gist.github.com/seanyen-msft/526825ad16de69550b075d511947cebc)  
  
I suspect it is related to the global initializer usage \(however I don’t know why it manifests along with my change\). Do you know the background why the global initializer was added? Is it related to thread-safe initialization prior to C\+\+11? Since C\+\+11 now supports thread-safe local static initializer, perhaps we can conditionally remove it? In my case, without the global initializer code, the SIGABRT just went away.

And can you help re-spin the CI to see if it works?
content.html:
In my setup, I can see the gz SIGABRT in my case. The call stack looks similar. https://gist.github.com/seanyen-msft/526825ad16de69550b075d511947cebc

I suspect it is related to the global initializer usage (however I don’t know why it manifests along with my change). Do you know the background why the global initializer was added? Is it related to thread-safe initialization prior to C++11? Since C++11 now supports thread-safe local static initializer, perhaps we can conditionally remove it? In my case, without the global initializer code, the SIGABRT just went away.

And can you help re-spin the CI to see if it works?

could the forward declarations above be replaced by a `class singletonType;` line added to this macro?

~~~
#define GZ_SINGLETON_DECLARE(visibility, singletonType) \
class singletonType; \
template class visibility ::SingletonT<singletonType>;
~~~
content.html:
could the forward declarations above be replaced by a class singletonType; line added to this macro?

#define GZ_SINGLETON_DECLARE(visibility, singletonType) \
class singletonType; \
template class visibility ::SingletonT<singletonType>;

pullrequest.title: [Gazebo9] Enabling dynamic linking for Windows build

content.raw: Just throwing it out here that this fixed my issues with Gazebo plugins on Windows. Loading plugins will cause protobuf issues if they’re statically linked to Gazebo, related to [this common](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/37051635/several-shared-object-using-same-proto-leading-the-the-error-file-already-exist) issue I believe.
content.html: Just throwing it out here that this fixed my issues with Gazebo plugins on Windows. Loading plugins will cause protobuf issues if they’re statically linked to Gazebo, related to this common issue I believe.

content.raw:
I am a bit confused by this conditional inclusion. Gazebo can be compiled only with C\+\+ >11 compilers, and has you added the `/Zc:__cplusplus` option for MSVC, then this condition will always be false.   
Perhaps we can just simply drop this code? Or I am missing something?
content.html:
I am a bit confused by this conditional inclusion. Gazebo can be compiled only with C++ >11 compilers, and has you added the /Zc:__cplusplus option for MSVC, then this condition will always be false.
Perhaps we can just simply drop this code? Or I am missing something?

pullrequest.title: [Gazebo9] Enabling dynamic linking for Windows build

content.raw: Usually many of them are safe to ignore. The original intent of this warning is to make sure the static data member only gets instanced in one DLL libraries. However IMHO, C4251 is not really a good indicator for that. Is there an central location for warning flags in Cmake files? Or just go ahead adding one in `gz_setup_windows`?
content.html: Usually many of them are safe to ignore. The original intent of this warning is to make sure the static data member only gets instanced in one DLL libraries. However IMHO, C4251 is not really a good indicator for that. Is there an central location for warning flags in Cmake files? Or just go ahead adding one in gz_setup_windows?

pullrequest.title: [Gazebo9] Enabling dynamic linking for Windows build

content.html: yeah, I think adding it in gz_setup_windows would be a good place, but let's save that for a separate pull request

pullrequest.title: [Gazebo9] Enabling dynamic linking for Windows build

content.raw:
it just occurs to me that changing a documented macro that takes arguments in a header file is like an API change, though our API checker didn't complain.

I think it would be cleaner to make a new macro called `GZ_ENUM_VISIBILITY` and replace all instances of `GZ_ENUM` in gazebo with the new macro. I'll see if we could also deprecate the `GZ_ENUM` macro.
content.html:
it just occurs to me that changing a documented macro that takes arguments in a header file is like an API change, though our API checker didn't complain.

I think it would be cleaner to make a new macro called GZ_ENUM_VISIBILITY and replace all instances of GZ_ENUM in gazebo with the new macro. I'll see if we could also deprecate the GZ_ENUM macro.

pullrequest.title: [Gazebo9] Enabling dynamic linking for Windows build

content.raw:
Thanks @{5bee878f5416561374c46bd9} !

One last questions, are we 100% sure that removing a private static attribute from a class is not changing its ABI? For sure it is not going to change the size of the class, but I am not personally 100% sure if it is changing the ABI in any other way \(and I wonder if the ABI checker considers this case\).
content.html:
Thanks @Sean Yen !

One last questions, are we 100% sure that removing a private static attribute from a class is not changing its ABI? For sure it is not going to change the size of the class, but I am not personally 100% sure if it is changing the ABI in any other way (and I wonder if the ABI checker considers this case).

pullrequest.title: [Gazebo9] Enabling dynamic linking for Windows build

content.raw:
KDE’s guidelines \( [https://community.kde.org/Policies/Binary\_Compatibility\_Issues\_With\_C%2B%2B#The\_Do.27s\_and\_Don.27ts](https://community.kde.org/Policies/Binary_Compatibility_Issues_With_C%2B%2B#The_Do.27s_and_Don.27ts) \) on this state:

> You can remove private static members **if** they are not called by any inline functions \(and have never been\).

As far as I can see the `myself` attribute was not called by any inline function, so as long as we trust KDE’s guidelines we should be good to go.
content.html:
KDE’s guidelines ( https://community.kde.org/Policies/Binary_Compatibility_Issues_With_C%2B%2B#The_Do.27s_and_Don.27ts ) on this state:

You can remove private static members if they are not called by any inline functions (and have never been).

As far as I can see the myself attribute was not called by any inline function, so as long as we trust KDE’s guidelines we should be good to go.

pullrequest.title: [Gazebo9] Enabling dynamic linking for Windows build

content.raw: I can't find an inline function calling `myself` either. I think that during years the ABI checker did not miss problems with ABI stability but we could produce a prerelease in the case that we want to be test the changes before going stable.
content.html: I can't find an inline function calling myself either. I think that during years the ABI checker did not miss problems with ABI stability but we could produce a prerelease in the case that we want to be test the changes before going stable.
